item.title: Summer Holiday with Robin
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Here are some pictures from the summerbreak activities with Robin Strike a pose I had an interview about Robin and me with a journalist from a local newspaper, this is the picture placed by the interview I was making paella and found the chicken in the box An sunny afternoon at the balcony Are you […]
item.content:encoded:
Here are some pictures from the summerbreak activities with Robin

Strike a pose

I had an interview about Robin and me with a journalist from a local newspaper, this is the picture placed by the interview

I was making paella and found the chicken in the box

An sunny afternoon at the balcony

Are you talking to me

Some people just leave their garbage at the street

Getting some fruit

Robin loves oranges and orange juice

She also like cherries and kiwi

Is their a fire somewhere

Buying some flowers

Walking in some surrounding nature

She likes to destroy boxes

Arrested because Robin pushed a motorcycle (was just for the fun with the local police)

Visiting the community vegetable garden

At the local skatepark

Looking at Rotterdam marathon

Visiting activities during Kingsday

We visit Robin’s friends frequently

Watching soccer

Wet Wet Wet

Swinging

A new transportation for Robin

Behind the drum kit

Visiting the community children farm

item.title: Bullseye
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: The Bullseye was published weekly by The Amalgamated Press based at Fleetway House In Farringdon Street, London. A boy’s story paper, it ran from 24th January 1931 to 21st July 1934, for a total of 183 issues. It incorporated ‘Surprise’ on 18th November 1933 and was itself subsequently converted into comic format and renamed ‘Film […]
item.content:encoded:
The Bullseye was published weekly by The Amalgamated Press based at Fleetway House In Farringdon Street, London.
A boy’s story paper, it ran from 24th January 1931 to 21st July 1934, for a total of 183 issues.
It incorporated ‘Surprise’ on 18th November 1933 and was itself subsequently converted into comic format and renamed ‘Film Picture Stories’.
During its run, it concentrated on producing stories with a hint of mystery and thrills.

item.title: Triumph
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: The Triumph was a British Story Paper for boys. It was published weekly by The Amalgamated Press based at Fleetway House in Farringdon Street, London. Following on from the demise of The Rocket, it ran from October 1924 to May 1940 for a total of 814 issues. During its long run it incorporated The Boy’s […]
item.content:encoded:
The Triumph was a British Story Paper for boys. It was published weekly by The Amalgamated Press based at Fleetway House in Farringdon Street, London.

Following on from the demise of The Rocket, it ran from October 1924 to May 1940 for a total of 814 issues.

During its long run it incorporated The Boy’s Friend in January 1928, then The Gem in January 1940 for a short spell before itself being merged with The Champion.

Billed in some of its issues as ‘Every Yarn’s A Thriller’, it featured a broad spectrum of thrilling adventure stories.

item.title: Pssst
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Pssst! (styled as pssst!) was a short-lived British comics magazine published by Never–Artpool in 1982. Pssst!, which lasted ten monthly issues, was an attempt to publish a British equivalent of the lavish French bande dessinée magazines. Bryan Talbot, Glenn Dakin, Shaky Kane, Paul Johnson, Stephen Baskerville, Ed Pinsent, John Watkiss, John Bolton, John Higgins, and […]
item.content:encoded:
Pssst! (styled as pssst!) was a short-lived British comics magazine published by Never–Artpool in 1982. Pssst!, which lasted ten monthly issues, was an attempt to publish a British equivalent of the lavish French bande dessinée magazines.

Bryan Talbot, Glenn Dakin, Shaky Kane, Paul Johnson, Stephen Baskerville, Ed Pinsent, John Watkiss, John Bolton, John Higgins, and Angus McKiewere amongst the many cartoonists published within the pages of pssst!. Early parts of Talbot’s The Adventures of Luther Arkwright were published in the comic.

Talbot feels that pssst! “…was the precursor of Escape and Deadline and the rest of the cascade of British adult comic mags that came out in the Eighties and Nineties.” Critic Russell Willis, on the other hand, wrote of the publication, “It tended towards Heavy Metal tits, ass and girls-with-butterfly-wings style over any lasting substance.”

item.title: The Miracle
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Apparently The Miracle debuted on 9 Feb 1935, but that might just be someone counting back the weeks from an issue, which isn’t always flawless. It was eventually merged with the similar Oracle, possibly not much later than the 1958 issue we have here, but also possibly during the 1959 changeover from AP to Fleetway. […]
item.content:encoded:
Apparently The Miracle debuted on 9 Feb 1935, but that might just be someone counting back the weeks from an issue, which isn’t always flawless.

It was eventually merged with the similar Oracle, possibly not much later than the 1958 issue we have here, but also possibly during the 1959 changeover from AP to Fleetway. The main audience would have been teenage girls amd young women, hence the stories being a mix of romance and human interest drama, a bit more grounded than those appearing in things like The Girls’ Crystal. These titles were quite profitable as it opened up an area of advertising beyond juvenile titles for things like cosmetics, sanitary products and the like It probably lost the younger readers to the romance comics and older ones to the growing number of true-life magazines aimed at women. The Oracle might well have been the last story paper AP/Fleetway published.

The Miracle Library ran for some time as a standard 5 x 7 “story paper library” running compilations of serials from the weekly. The 1949 issues have adverts for early numbers; IIRC it was around 1949 that paper rationing was relaxed or ended. Later in its life it seems to have morphed into a line of pulp paperbacks that survived until at least 1971.

Information thanks to BoomboxTestarossa

UPDATE 2024-09

item.title: Robin3
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Some pictures from activities with my birdfriend Robin, she is a woman sun parakeet from 3,5 years old and has become my greatest friend and pleasure these years We often go walking when the weather is nice, at least 12 degrees and sun with not much wind. One of her favorite activities, crushing boxes Look […]
item.content:encoded:
Some pictures from activities with my birdfriend Robin, she is a woman sun parakeet from 3,5 years old and has become my greatest friend and pleasure these years

We often go walking when the weather is nice, at least 12 degrees and sun with not much wind.

One of her favorite activities, crushing boxes

Look how tall i am

She loves meeting other animals

A pool in the park

Taking care of her wings

She loves apples and carrots among many other things

Me and my shadow

Walking in the nature

Taking a rest

Doing some shopping, she is allowed in most shops where i do my shopping and she has becomes a celebrity in the neighborhood

She is beautiful

Easter Brunch

Just sitting on my knee

What’s the matter ?

Walking on the street
